value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">31</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The RxxxxReader.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The audience at the 
            <choice>
              <sic>Elizabetahn</sic>
              <corr>Elizabethan</corr>
            </choice> play was not an 
            <choice>
              <sic>audiejce</sic>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of readers. They had to draw 
            <choice>
              <sic>int</sic>
              <corr>in</corr>
            </choice> the play through their ears, through their eyes</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">They could not deepen the impression and renew</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it at a table in a private room. This perhaps explains</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the scarcity of Elizabethan criticism; and the general nature</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of what criticism there is. Both <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-psid" key="Sidney, Philip">Sidney</rs> and <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-bjon" key="Jonson, Ben">Jonson</rs></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">deal with the general rules of poetry; not with the 
            <choice>
              <sic>particuar</sic>
              <corr>particular</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">play or poem. The lack of a book of the words accounts too</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">for the long pause, between <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wsha" key="Shakespeare, William">
            <choice>
              <sic>Sahkepares</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare's</corr>
            </choice></rs> death</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and the eighteenth century, 
            <choice>
              <sic>whe</sic>
              <corr>when</corr>
            </choice> the plays of 
            <choice>
              <sic>Shakepere</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">even hang suspended, 
            <choice>
              <sic>unrea ised</sic>
              <corr>unrealised</corr>
            </choice>. They had to wait until the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">printed book was in many hands before they received</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the life that the reader 
            <choice>
              <sic>co fers</sic>
              <corr>confers</corr>
            </choice> Much that was lost</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in the playhouse was 
            <choice>
              <sic>disocvered</sic>
              <corr>discovered</corr>
            </choice> in the private room.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But 
            <choice>
              <sic>mu h</sic>
              <corr>much</corr>
            </choice> was lost for ever when the playhouse shut.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Txmxmmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxm We have lost the sound of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">spoken word; all that the sight of the actors bodies</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">suggests to the mind through the eye. We have lost the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">sense of being part of the audience. We miss a 
            <choice>
              <sic>th usnd</sic>
              <corr>thousand</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">suggestions that the dramatist conveyed by the inflection</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of voice, by gesture, by the placing of the actors bodies.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">This can still be proved by comparing our impression</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>aft</sic>
              <corr>after</corr>
            </choice> seeing the play acted with our impression after reading</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the play alone. But as the actor 
            <choice>
              <sic>ipmports</sic>
              <corr>imports</corr>
            </choice> much that is of</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">his own day, and 
            <choice>
              <sic>foreing</sic>
              <corr>[foreign?]</corr>
            </choice> to the past, so that there is t</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">still something in every Elizabethan play sunk beyond recall.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">We can be sure then that the reader has been</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in existence for round about four hundred years. But his</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">life history is an obscure one. At some point his ear must</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">have lost 
            <choice>
              <sic>i s</sic>
              <corr>its</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>acutness</sic>
              <corr>acuteness</corr>
            </choice>; then his 
            <choice>
              <sic>eyees</sic>
              <corr>eyes</corr>
            </choice> became dulled.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Later he became more conscious of the suggestions and echoes</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in words. He imported much into the 
            <choice>
              <sic>w itten</sic>
              <corr>written</corr>
            </choice> word that was</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">unintended xxxxxxx by the writer. A word given in its</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Elizabethan spelling brings in suggestions that give it</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">almost another meaning. The words suggest other manners,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">other clothes. They accent the contrast between one society</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and another. And as the habit of reading becomes universal,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">many 
            <choice>
              <sic>varities</sic>
              <corr>varieties</corr>
            </choice> of reader are created. There are the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>s ecialised</sic>
              <corr>specialised</corr>
            </choice> readers whose power of 
            <choice>
              <sic>darwing</sic>
              <corr>drawing</corr>
            </choice> out the</l>
